title: 106_hr1572
content:
The "Digital Signature Act of 1999" mandates federal agencies to recognize digital signatures as equivalent to written signatures for authenticating electronically formatted documents. This recognition will take effect one year after the enactment of the Act. The Director, in consultation with industry, must develop digital signature guidelines and standards for Federal agencies within 6 months of the Act's enactment. These guidelines will ensure secure and interoperable use of digital signatures, including technical security requirements, validation criteria, and interoperability specifications. The Director will establish interoperability specifications for Federal digital signature products and services in coordination with the National Policy Panel. Periodic reviews and revisions of guidelines and standards will be conducted as needed. SEC. 4. VALIDATION OF PRODUCTS.

The Director will evaluate the conformance of digital signature infrastructure products with guidelines and standards, making the results available to Federal agencies and the public.

SEC. 5. ELECTRONIC CERTIFICATION AND MANAGEMENT SYSTEMS. SEC. 5. ELECTRONIC CERTIFICATION AND MANAGEMENT SYSTEMS.

The Director will establish criteria for electronic certification and management systems for Federal agencies within 6 months of this Act. A program will be created to evaluate systems' conformance, and a list of approved systems will be maintained and provided to Federal agencies. SEC. 6. REPORTS.

The Director must provide Congress with reports every year, starting 6 months after this Act is enacted. Reports will cover the usage of digital signatures by Federal agencies, evaluation of their digital signature infrastructures, assessment of electronic certification systems, a list of approved systems, and evaluations conducted under section 4. The Under Secretary will establish a National Policy Panel for Digital Signatures within 90 days of this Act. The Panel will consist of government, academic, and industry experts to develop model practices for certification authorities ensuring accuracy and security in digital signature systems. The National Policy Panel for Digital Signatures will develop standards and audit requirements for certification authorities to ensure accuracy and security in digital signature systems. The Panel will coordinate with the Director and provide administrative support. A report with recommendations will be submitted to Congress within one year of the Act's enactment. SEC. 8. DEFINITIONS. The Act defines key terms related to digital certificates and signatures, including certification authorities, digital certificates, digital signatures, digital signature infrastructure, Director, and electronic certification and management. The Act defines key terms related to digital certificates and signatures, including electronic certification and management systems for applying digital signatures and the role of the Under Secretary of Commerce for Technology.
